chapter.title: Executive Summary
chapter.simpara: This chapter provides a high-level overview of the project.

section.title: Technologies used
section.simpara: This project incorporates the following technologies:

section.title: Focus on content, not formatting
section.simpara: This documentation system leverages open-source tools to create professional documents without worrying about the format. It provides several advantages:

listitem.simpara: Format is based on semantic content

section.title: Create professional documents based on templates
section.simpara: This package provides the ej command for creating documents. The ej command is short for engagement journal and does several things:

listitem.simpara: Creates a working directory containing a template engagement journal
Enables the author to work with plain-text files
converts plain-text, lightweight markup into docbook
converts docbook into well-formatted output, such as PDF

note.simpara: The ej command provides the above features now.

section.title: Manage a central document repository
section.simpara: The ejadm command administers a collection of documents. In the future, the ejadm command will provide a front-end to version control and publishing, enabling users to:

listitem.simpara: List documents by author, client name, or document title
Check-out document modules; e.g., runbook procedures

important.simpara: The ejadm command does not yet provide the features listed above.

section.title: Another scope element
section.simpara: Use asciidoc in your source to denote things that should be bold or italicized.

itemizedlist.title: List titles are optional and begin with a dot (no space)

listitem.simpara: First bullet point in no implied order of progression
Denote commands, such as the cat /proc/cpuinfo command, in backticks

orderedlist.title: List titles are bold, and this portion is also italicized

listitem.simpara: Numbered lists are good for procedures

section.title: Publican versions
section.simpara: Publican embeds a product version number in the title of the document. This is really annoying, but fits within the design goals of Publican.

listitem.simpara: Rebuild by running the make all command

note.simpara: A future version of the ej command will probably do this for you.

section.title: Low-latency Environment
section.simpara: This solution does not require any background process (also known as a daemon) to run. This avoids any impact on low-latency requirements for RHEL.

section.title: DNS Architecture
section.simpara: Any network infrastructure based on TCP/IP protocols should have a well-designed DNS. This document provides work-arounds for an infrastructure in which DNS is less than optimal.

listitem.simpara: Lack of heirarchical delegation to subdomains
Pre-populating the /etc/hosts file provides unique names for each record
A naming standard has been developed for adding entries to the /etc/hosts file
Use RHN Satellite Server to push out the /etc/hosts file

section.title: Multicast traffic
section.simpara: Red Hat Cluster Suite requires multicast traffic on intervening switches.

section.title: Implement multicast correctly
section.simpara: Really, I mean a $35 D-Link switch can do it.

section.title: Design a standard operating environment around Client Name's Satellite Server
section.simpara: Client Name has an RHN Satellite Server. We should develop a plan to:

listitem.simpara: Define standard configurations for Client Name RHEL servers
Add existing servers to the satellite server for management of
Configuration files that deviate from stock. RHN Satellite server provides basic revision control for config files.

section.title: Disable unnecessary services
section.simpara: A number of services are enabled by default and can be disabled to save resources. The following code snippet can be added as a standard part of %post in a baseline kickstart.
section.screen:
#!/bin/bash
unnecessary=" avahi-daemon pcscd bluetooth hidd iptables cpuspeed "
prog=$(basename $0) def_run=$(grep '^id.*initdefault' /etc/inittab | cut -d: -f2)
for svc in $unnecessary; do chkconfig --list $svc | grep -q "$def_run:on" && continue logger -t $prog "disabling $svc" service $svc stop chkconfig $svc off done
file=/etc/sysconfig/network grep -q NOZEROCONF $file || \ ( logger -t $prog "disabling zeroconf" echo "NOZEROCONF=disabled" >> $file )
section.simpara: The script reports its actions in /var/log/messages, as shown in this example output:
section.screen: Nov 17 16:51:42 hostname disable-services: disabling avahi-daemon Nov 17 16:51:42 hostname disable-services: disabling pcscd Nov 17 16:51:44 hostname disable-services: disabling bluetooth Nov 17 16:51:44 hostname disable-services: disabling hidd Nov 17 16:51:44 hostname disable-services: disabling iptables Nov 17 16:51:44 hostname disable-services: disabling cpuspeed

section.title: Centralized logging
section.simpara: We should consider making rsyslog a part of the baseline build. A centralized log host can be virtualized and addressed using a DNS CNAME, such as syslog01. This would allow the virtual host to be relocated as needed without impacting existing configurations.

sidebar.simpara: Rsyslog is an enhanced multi-threaded syslogd supporting, among others, MySQL, syslog/tcp, RFC 3195, permitted sender lists, filtering on any message part, and fine grain output format control. It is quite compatible to stock sysklogd and can be used as a drop-in replacement. Its advanced features make it suitable for enterprise-class, encryption protected syslog relay chains while at the same time being very easy to setup for the novice user.

section.title: Event correlation
section.simpara: Client Name should consider installing Simple Event Correlator (SEC) on the syslog host.
See http://simple-evcorr.sourceforge.net for more information on SEC.

blockquote.simpara: SEC is an open source and platform independent event correlation tool that was designed to fill the gap between commercial event correlation systems and homegrown solutions that usually comprise a few simple shell scripts. SEC accepts input from regular files, named pipes, and standard input, and can thus be employed as an event correlator for any application that is able to write its output events to a file stream. The SEC configuration is stored in text files as rules, each rule specifying an event matching condition, an action list, and optionally a Boolean expression whose truth value decides whether the rule can be applied at a given moment. Regular expressions, Perl subroutines, etc. are used for defining event matching conditions. SEC can produce output events by executing user-specified shell scripts or programs (e.g., snmptrap or mail), by writing messages to pipes or files, and by various other means.

SEC has been successfully applied in various domains like network management, system monitoring, data security, intrusion detection, log file monitoring and analysis, etc. The applications SEC has been used or integrated with include HP OpenView NNM and Operations, CiscoWorks, BMC Patrol, Nagios, SNMPTT, Snort IDS, Prelude IDS, etc.

section.title: Bash Scripting
section.simpara: Client Name admins should develop Bash scripting skills. I spent some time with the Linux team to cover scripting and command-line navigation. Using scripts to automate management tasks provides useful benefits:

listitem.simpara: Ability to test scripts before running in production
Avoids risk of entering commands by hand on production servers
Over time, build a library of common scripts

formalpara.title: Free, self-study resources
formalpara.para: The following two resources are freely available online and provide a great reference for individuals who prefer to self-study.

formalpara.title: Instructor-led training
formalpara.para: For instructor-led training with labs, Red Hat offers a course that includes Bash scripting and Linux command-line skills. RH033 Red Hat Linux Essentials for Windows Professionals and other Operating System Users is available in a traditional corporate classroom environment or as a virtual Internet-based class.
